image.title: Glaser's recollections on choosing Caltech for his graduate studies.
image.caption: Excerpt from: Donald Glaser, “The Bubble Chamber, Bioengineering, Business Consulting, and Neurobiology,” an oral history conducted in 2003-2004 by Eric Vettel. Regional Oral Office, The Bancroft Library, University of California, Berkeley, 2006.

image.title: Glaser's recollections of Robert A. Millikan, one of Caltech founders, and a Nobel Laureate.
image.caption: Excerpt from: Donald Glaser, “The Bubble Chamber, Bioengineering, Business Consulting, and Neurobiology,” an oral history conducted in 2003-2004 by Eric Vettel. Regional Oral Office, The Bancroft Library, University of California, Berkeley, 2006.

image.title: Robert Andrew Millikan standing in front of Throop Hall.
image.caption: Undated

image.title: Excerpts from Millikan's oil-drop experiment laboratory notebooks, which won him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1923.
image.caption: October 1911-March 1912

image.title: “Jesus saves but Millikan gets credit.” Caltech students added their own bit of graffiti to this steam shovel excavating foundations for the Crellin Laboratory of Chemistry.
Glaser's recollections of his work with Nobel Laureate Carl Anderson.
image.caption: Excerpt from: Donald Glaser, “The Bubble Chamber, Bioengineering, Business Consulting, and Neurobiology,” an oral history conducted in 2003-2004 by Eric Vettel. Regional Oral Office, The Bancroft Library, University of California, Berkeley, 2006.

image.title: Carl D. Anderson beside his apparatus, with which he discovered the positron in 1932. This apparatus measures the energies of the individual cosmic ray-particles."
Carl Anderson’s teaching notes on Airy’s experiment.
Glaser's recollections of Richard C. Tolman. At Caltech, Tolman served as professor of physical chemistry and mathematical physics.
image.caption: Excerpt from: Donald Glaser, “The Bubble Chamber, Bioengineering, Business Consulting, and Neurobiology,” an oral history conducted in 2003-2004 by Eric Vettel. Regional Oral Office, The Bancroft Library, University of California, Berkeley, 2006.

image.title: The first page of one of Tolman papers, "The Present Status of Cosmology."
Glaser's recollections of William Smythe. Famous for his electricity and magnetism course at Caltech, Smythe taught at least six Nobel Prize winners.
image.caption: Excerpt from: Donald Glaser, “The Bubble Chamber, Bioengineering, Business Consulting, and Neurobiology,” an oral history conducted in 2003-2004 by Eric Vettel. Regional Oral Office, The Bancroft Library, University of California, Berkeley, 2006.

image.title: William Smythe’s lecture notes on freely charged cylinder.
